element.name: a
element.title: vitamin A
element.intro: Vitamin A is needed for the immune system, healthy skin, and for low light eyesight. Beta carotene from plant sources is also thought to work as an antioxidant. Fruit and vegetables contain beta carotene rather than vitamin A itself (that is only found in animal source foods). However, the body can make vitamin A from beta carotene.

element.name: b1
element.title: vitamin B1
element.intro: Along with other B vitamins, vitamin B1 (thiamin) helps break down food and keep nerves and tissues healthy.

element.name: b2
element.title: vitamin B2
element.intro: Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) helps break down energy in carbohydrates, and helps the health of skin and hair, eyes, and nerves. The best source of riboflavin is in diary products, but it is also found in grains, cereals, meat, and fish.

element.name: b3
element.title: vitamin B3
element.intro: Vitamin B3 (niacin) helps release energy from food during digestion, and sustains the nervous and digestive systems.

element.name: b5
element.title: vitamin B5
element.intro: Alongside other B vitamins, vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) helps metabolise foods. It may also help the body fight infections. Pantothenic acid is widely found across many food groups.

element.name: b6
element.title: vitamin b6
element.intro: Vitamin B6 helps the body digest protein, helps the nervous system, and the production of haemoglobin. Taking too much B6 in supplements may be harmful, leading to a loss of feeling in the arms and legs.

element.name: b9
element.title: folic acid B9
element.intro: Vitamin B9 (folic acid) in its natural form is called folate. Fruit and vegetables are a good source of this vitamin. Folate helps with cell division and with the manufacture of red blood cells. During pregnancy, it plays an important role in the development of the foetus.

element.name: c
element.title: vitamin C
element.intro: Vegetables and fruit are excellent sources of vitamin C. Vitamin C supports the health of cells and tissue, the healing of wounds, and generally helps the body fight infection. Vitamin C cannot be stored in the body, so eating foods containing the vitamin on a daily basis is recommended.

element.name: e
element.title: vitamin E
element.intro: Vitamin E is an antioxidant that helps our immune system and protects against cell damage. It is found mainly in plant oils like olive oil, but also in nuts, seeds, and cereals.

element.name: k
element.title: vitamin K
element.intro: Fruit and vegetables can contain high levels of vitamin K. The vitamin is good for blood clotting and helping wounds to heal.

element.name: iron
element.title: iron
element.intro: Iron is a very important mineral used in red blood cells to transport oxygen around our body. A lack of iron causes anaemia, but taking too much iron in supplements can be harmful.

element.name: magnesium
element.title: magnesium
element.intro: Magnesium helps the body digest food and extract energy. It supports bone health, helps with muscle contraction, and heart health.

element.name: potassium
element.title: potassium
element.intro: Potassium is involved in controlling body fluid levels, regulating blood pressure, and maintaining the bodyâ€™s electrical impulses.

element.name: zinc
element.title: zinc
element.intro: Zinc is an important trace element. It helps our body make new cells, heal wounds, and process food. It also plays a role in taste and smell.
